Background Analysis.Challenges and performance gaps in the i: The agriculture sector, particularly urban farming, faces significant challenges that hinder optimal performance and productivity. One of the primary issues is the lack of knowledge and skills among practitioners regarding modern farming techniques, particularly hydroponics. Many individuals involved in urban farming may not be familiar with the various hydroponic systems, their setup, and maintenance, leading to inefficient operations and lower crop yields. Additionally, the industry is often plagued by insufficient adherence to regulatory frameworks and best practices, resulting in non-compliance with food safety standards and workplace safety protocols. This lack of compliance not only jeopardizes the health of consumers but also exposes farmers to legal liabilities and financial penalties. Furthermore, the rapid urbanization and limited space in urban environments create additional pressure on urban farmers to maximize output while minimizing resource use, which requires a thorough understanding of advanced farming techniques and sustainability practices. The performance gaps are further exacerbated by the need for ongoing education and training, as many existing practitioners may not have access to updated information on emerging technologies and practices within the hydroponics sector.
Background Analysis.Training needs necessary to address thes: To effectively address the identified performance gaps, targeted training programs focusing on hydroponics and urban farming practices are essential. Such training should encompass a comprehensive curriculum that covers the types, purposes, and functions of farming equipment and machinery, as well as the standard operating procedures (SOPs) necessary for efficient farming operations. Additionally, training must emphasize the importance of Good Agricultural Practices (GAPs) and compliance with prevailing regulations concerning food safety and workplace safety and health (WSH) practices. Practitioners need hands-on experience in setting up and maintaining hydroponic systems, which should be integrated into the training through practical demonstrations and real-world applications. Moreover, training programs should also include modules on equipment cleaning and maintenance techniques to ensure that farming operations are conducted in a hygienic and safe manner. By equipping urban farmers with the necessary skills and knowledge, the training can significantly enhance their ability to perform farming activities effectively, comply with regulations, and maintain high standards of food safety, ultimately leading to improved productivity and sustainability in urban agriculture.
Background Analysis.Job roles that would benefit from the tr: Several job roles within the agriculture sector, particularly those focused on urban farming and hydroponics, would greatly benefit from the proposed training. Urban farmers, who are directly involved in planting, cultivating, and harvesting crops, would gain valuable insights into the best practices for hydroponics, enabling them to enhance their operational efficiency and output. Additionally, farm managers and supervisors, who oversee the daily operations of urban farms, would benefit from understanding the regulatory frameworks and compliance requirements essential for maintaining safe and productive farming environments. Agricultural technicians and support staff, who assist in the maintenance and operation of farming equipment, would also find the training beneficial as it would equip them with the necessary skills to ensure that equipment is properly cleaned and maintained, thereby reducing the risk of operational downtime. Furthermore, individuals looking to enter the urban farming sector, such as aspiring entrepreneurs or community gardeners, would find the training invaluable as it provides a solid foundation in hydroponics and urban farming practices, preparing them for successful careers in this growing industry. Overall, the training would cater to a diverse range of roles within the urban farming sector, fostering a more knowledgeable and skilled workforce capable of addressing the challenges faced by the industry.

Sequencing Analysis.Sequencing Explanation: For this course, the step-by-step sequencing is employed to systematically build learners' knowledge and skills in urban farming with hydroponics. This methodology is crucial as it breaks down complex concepts into manageable units, enabling learners to gain foundational knowledge before advancing to practical applications. The progression is designed to foster a comprehensive understanding of hydroponics, ensuring that learners can effectively perform farming activities and comply with necessary regulations in real-world scenarios.

LU1.Title: Urban Farming and Hydroponics Foundations
LU1.Description: LU1 establishes the fundamental principles of hydroponics, providing learners with a thorough understanding of the various hydroponic systems, their components, and operational procedures. This unit addresses the performance gap of learners struggling to understand hydroponic systems by equipping them with the knowledge needed to set up and maintain these systems effectively. The integration of practical applications, such as assembling a basic hydroponic system, ensures that learners can apply their theoretical knowledge in a hands-on context.

LU2.Title: Urban Farming Techniques and Practices
LU2.Description: Building upon the foundational knowledge from LU1, LU2 delves into advanced techniques and regulatory considerations for urban farming. This unit focuses on the practical aspects of executing farming operations in compliance with regulations and Good Agricultural Practices (GAPs), addressing the performance gap related to compliance knowledge. Learners will engage in activities that promote proficiency in adhering to safety standards and maintaining equipment, thereby gaining essential skills to minimize operational disruptions and enhance productivity in urban farming environments.

Sequencing Analysis.Conclusion: Overall, the structured sequencing of these learning units is designed to address the performance gaps identified in urban farming while equipping learners with the necessary attributes to excel in their roles within the hydroponics sector.

Assessment Phrasing:
Oral Questioning:
An oral questioning assessment will evaluate candidates' understanding and application of hydroponic farming principles and practices through direct interaction.

The Oral Questioning assessment focuses on assessing candidates' comprehension of hydroponics and their ability to articulate best practices in urban farming.
Candidates will participate in a structured oral examination where they respond to questions related to hydroponics and urban farming practices.

Type of Evidence:
•	For LO1: Candidates will explain standard operating procedures for operating hydroponic farming equipment and perform related tasks during questioning.
•	For LO2: Candidates will discuss regulations, WSH practices, and housekeeping rules relevant to urban farming operations.
Manner of Submission:
•	Candidates will not submit written work but will verbally respond to assessors' questions in a timed session.
•	Responses may be recorded for review and assessment purposes.
Marking Process: Assessors will evaluate the submissions based on a rubric that considers:
•	Clarity of Explanation: Assessors will evaluate how clearly candidates articulate their understanding of hydroponic systems and practices.
•	Depth of Knowledge: Assessors will assess the candidates' ability to provide detailed and accurate responses to questions.
•	Application of Concepts: Assessors will evaluate how well candidates relate theoretical knowledge to practical applications in hydroponics.
Retention Period:
•	Recorded oral responses and assessment records will be retained for 2 years for compliance and auditing purposes.
